Executive Director, National Security Professional Development Integration Office }} '''William A. Navas Jr.''' (born December 15, 1942) is a retired [[United States Army]] [[Major General (United States)|Major General]] who served as the Director of the [[Army National Guard]]. He is also the first Puerto Rican to be named an [[Assistant Secretary of the Navy]]. ==Early life and education== Navas was born in [[Mayaguez, Puerto Rico]] on December 15, 1942.U.S. House Appropriations Committee, [http://ia700305.us.archive.org/30/items/departmentofdefe032000unit/departmentofdefe032000unit_djvu.txt Hearing Record], Defense Appropriations for 1997, Biographical sketch, William A. Navas Jr., 1996U.S. Senate Armed Services Committee, [https://books.google.com/books?id=aLkPAAAAIAAJ&q=william+navas+jr.+born+1942&dq=william+navas+jr.+born+1942&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5CuWUYquLo_d4AP314G4Ag&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA Hearing Record], Nominations before the Senate Armed Services Committee, first session, 107th Congress, 2002, page 1009 His family has a long tradition of military service, including his grandfather, [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] Antonio M. Navas, who served in both World Wars. His father, [[Captain (United States)#Captain.28Ground and Air Forces.29|Captain]] William A. Navas Sr. served in [[World War II]] and had a successful career in civil engineering upon his retirement from the military.Puerto Rico Herald, [http://www.puertorico-herald.org/issues/2001/vol5n29/ProfNavas-en.html Puerto Rico Profile: William A. Navas Jr.], July 10, 2001 Navas received his primary and secondary education in his hometown of [[Mayag端ez]]. After graduating from high school, he enrolled in the [[University of Puerto Rico, Mayag端ez Campus]], and received his [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[civil engineering]].National Guard Bureau, [http://www.ngb.army.mil/ngbgomo/library/bio/navas_wa.htm Biography, William A. Navas Jr.], accessed May 17, 2013 He joined the Beta-Activo Chapter of [[Phi Sigma Alpha]] fraternity, and served as chapter president from 1963 to 1964.Beta-Activo Chapter, [http://betafsaactivo.tripod.com/id8.html List of Presidents], accessed May 17, 2013 In addition to his degree from the University of Puerto Rico, Navas completed a Master of Science degree in Management Engineering at the [[University of Bridgeport]].Gale Group, Inc., [https://books.google.com/books?ei=wzeWUa7gEfj84AO55IH4CQ&id=Yd91AAAAMAAJ&dq=%22william+a.+navas%22+university+bridgeport&q=%22william+a.+navas%22 Who's Who Among Hispanic Americans 1994-95], 1994, page 566 Navas completed Army qualification courses for the Engineer, [[Military Police Corps (United States)|Military Police]], and [[Infantry Branch (United States)|Infantry]] branches. He also completed specialty courses including [[Jungle Warfare]]. He was the Distinguished Graduate of his class at the [[United States Army Command and General Staff College]], and graduated from the [[Inter-American Defense College]]. Navas also completed the Program for Senior Managers in Government at [[Harvard University|Harvard University's]] [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]].National Guard Bureau, [http://www.ngb.army.mil/ngbgomo/library/bio/navas_wa.htm Biography, William A. Navas Jr.], accessed May 17, 2013 ==Career== Navas completed the [[Reserve Officers' Training Corps|ROTC]] program while in college, and joined the [[United States Army]] as a [[Second Lieutenant#United States|Second Lieutenant]] of [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|Engineers]]. He served more than five years on active duty, primarily in [[West Germany]]. From 1968 to 1969 he served in [[Vietnam]] as Commander of Company A, 168th Engineer Battalion.U.S. House Appropriations Committee, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Tvn-LTw5FbkC&q=%22william+a.+navas%22+vietnam&dq=%22william+a.+navas%22+vietnam&hl=en&sa=X&ei=yDOWUaDhHJO64APE24CoCA&ved=0CFsQ6AEwCQ Hearing Record], Military Construction Appropriations for 1990, Biographical sketch, William A. Navas Jr., 1989, page 351 In 1970 Navas joined his family's construction business, (Navas y Moreda),Associated General Contractors of America, [https://books.google.com/books?id=sXoqAQAAIAAJ&q=%22william+a.+navas%22+navas+y+moreda&dq=%22william+a.+navas%22+navas+y+moreda&hl=en&sa=X&ei=sSyWUcrrG4bq8QSYgYHwDQ&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA Constructor magazine], Volume 61, 1979 and became a member of the [[Puerto Rico Army National Guard]]. He advanced through a series of command and staff assignments, including command of the 125th Military Police Battalion, 1st Battalion, 296th Infantry Regiment and Combined Task Force, 193rd Infantry Brigade, attaining the rank of Colonel in 1981.U.S. Senate Appropriations Committee, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Pda5HJ9hr-gC&q=%22william+a.+navas%22+193rd+brigade&dq=%22william+a.+navas%22+193rd+brigade&hl=en&sa=X&ei=GS2WUbTjDIWY9QSvxoEo&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA Hearing Record], Military Construction Appropriations for Fiscal Year 1992, Biographical sketch, William A. Navas Jr., 1991, page 117 In 1981 he became a full-time member of the National Guard. After serving in several assignments at the Headquarters of the [[Puerto Rico National Guard]], in 1987 he was selected to succeed [[Richard D. Dean]] as Deputy Director of the [[Army National Guard]] and promoted to [[Brigadier General (United States)|Brigadier General]].U.S. House Armed Services Committee, [https://books.google.com/books?id=0YGUof6THQgC&q=%22william+a.+navas%22+deputy+director+army+national+guard&dq=%22william+a.+navas%22+deputy+director+army+national+guard&hl=en&sa=X&ei=dzSWUbKxIpOv4APc4IH4DA&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBA Hearing Record], National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1990, Biographical sketch, William A. Navas Jr., 1989, page 151 In 1990 he was chosen for the position of Vice Chief of the [[National Guard Bureau]] and promoted to Major General.Executive Publications, Inc., [https://books.google.com/books?ei=qy2WUfXiMYvI9QStkoHgBw&id=c38HAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22william+a.+navas%22+deputy+director&q=%22william+a.+navas%22 Government Executive magazine], Volume 22, 1990, page 54 Navas served as Vice Chief until 1992, when he became Executive Officer of the [[Reserve Forces Policy Board]].Brassey's Inc., [https://books.google.com/books?id=sFvfAAAAMAAJ&q=%22william+a.+navas%22+reserve+forces+policy+board&dq=%22william+a.+navas%22+reserve+forces+policy+board&hl=en&sa=X&ei=PC6WUeLIEpDI9QTt5YDQCQ&ved=0CEMQ6AEwAw The All-Volunteer Force: Thirty Years of Service], 2004, page 364 From September 1994 through October 1995 Navas was Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Reserve Affairs.U.S. Senate Armed Services Committee, [https://books.google.com/books?id=aLkPAAAAIAAJ&q=william+navas+jr.+born+1942&dq=william+navas+jr.+born+1942&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5CuWUYquLo_d4AP314G4Ag&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA Hearing Record], Nominations before the Senate Armed Services Committee, first session, 107th Congress, 2002, page 1009 In October, 1995 Navas was assigned as Director of the Army National Guard, and he served until May, 1998.Puerto Rico Herald, [http://www.puertorico-herald.org/issues/2004/vol8n45/NavyOfficialEncourages.html Navy Official Encourages Military Diversity In Globalized World], September 24, 2004 He was succeeded by [[Roger C. Schultz]].Bob Haskell, National Guard Bureau, On Guard, [http://www.nationalguard.mil/news/theonguard/1998/1998-06.pdf Schultz Assumes Director's Post], June, 1998, page 3 From June, 1998 until retiring from the military in October, 1998 Navas was a Special Assistant in the Office of the [[Vice Chief of Staff of the United States Army]].National Guard Bureau, [http://www.ngb.army.mil/ngbgomo/library/bio/navas_wa.htm Biography, William A. Navas Jr.], accessed May 17, 2013 ===Assistant Secretary of the Navy=== [[File:US Navy 070609-N-7732W-603 The Honorable William A. Navas Jr., the assistant Secretary of the Navy (Manpower and Reserve Affairs), is greeted by sideboys upon his arrival aboard guided-missile destroyer USS Howard (DDG 83).jpg|thumb|left|upright|Navas in June 2007, being greeted by U.S. Navy sailors as he boards the {{USS|Howard|DDG-83}}.]] After retiring from the military Navas became the Chairman of the American Veteran's Committee for Puerto Rico Self-Determination, an organization which he co-founded.[http://www.hispanianews.com/archive/2004/08/28/02.htm Hispanic Magazine honors March Gen. William A. Navas], August 28, 2004 On June 6, 2001 Navas was nominated by [[George W. Bush|President George W. Bush]] to serve as the [[Assistant Secretary of the Navy (Manpower and Reserve Affairs)]]. He was sworn in on July 17, 2001, and served through January, 2008.Washington Post, [http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/73453092.html?dids=73453092:73453092&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=May+31%2C+2001&author=&pub=The+Washington+Post&desc=Bush+Announces+Customs%2C+Other+Nominations&pqatl=google Bush Announces Customs, Other Nominations], May 31, 2001U.S. Navy, [http://www.navy.mil/navydata/bios/navybio.asp?bioID=16 Biography, William A. Navas Jr.], 2009 From 2008 to 2011 Navas served as Executive Director of the National Security Professional Development Integration Office at the [[United States Department of Defense]], the first individual to hold this position.dawson & Associates, [http://www.dawsonassociates.com/major-general-navas-joins-dawson-associates/ Major General Navas Joins Dawson & Associates], 2011 {{clr}} ==Later work== Since 2011, Navas has been a Senior Advisor at Dawson & Associates, a [[Washington, D.C.]] consulting firm.dawson & Associates, [https://www.dawsonassociates.com/tag/our-team/page/4/ Our Team], profile, William A.
